examples.x: Would you like a sandwich?
Would you have dinner with me on Friday?

senses.definition: used to say what you like, love, hate, etc.

examples.cf: would like, love, hate, prefer, etc. something
examples.x: I'd love a coffee.

examples.cf: would like, etc. to do something
examples.x: I'd be only too glad to help.

examples.cf: would like, etc. somebody to do something
examples.x: I'd hate you to think I was criticizing you.
I'd rather come with you.
I'd rather you came with us.

senses.definition: used as the past form of will when reporting what somebody has said or thought

examples.x: He said he would be here at eight o'clock (= His words were: ‘I will be there at eight o'clock.’).
She asked if I would help.
They told me that they probably wouldn't come.

senses.definition: used for talking about the result of an event that you imagine

examples.x: She'd look better with shorter hair.
If you went to see him, he would be delighted.
Hurry up! It would be a shame to miss the beginning of the play.
She'd be a fool to accept it (= if she accepted).

senses.definition: used for describing a possible action or event that did not in fact happen, because something else did not happen first

examples.x: If I had seen the advertisement in time, I would have applied for the job.
They would never have met if she hadn't gone to Emma's party.

senses.definition: used for saying why somebody does something

examples.cf: so that somebody/something would do something
examples.x: She burned the letters so that her husband would never read them.

examples.cf: in order that somebody/something would do something
examples.x: He worked hard in order that he would pass all his exams.

senses.definition: used for saying what you want to happen

examples.x: I wish that you'd be quiet for a minute.

senses.definition: used to show that somebody/something was not willing or refused to do something

examples.x: She wouldn't change it, even though she knew it was wrong.
My car wouldn't start this morning.

senses.definition: used to ask somebody politely to do something

examples.x: Would you mind leaving us alone for a few minutes?
Would you open the door for me, please?

senses.definition: used to give opinions that you are not certain about

examples.x: I would imagine the job will take about two days.
I'd say he was about fifty.

senses.definition: used to give advice

examples.x: I wouldn't have any more to drink, if I were you.

senses.definition: used for talking about things that often happened in the past

examples.x: When my parents were away, my grandmother would take care of me.
He'd always be the first to offer to help.

senses.definition: used for talking about behaviour that you think is typical

examples.x: ‘She said it was your fault.’ ‘Well, she would say that, wouldn't she? She's never liked me.’

senses.definition: used to express a strong wish

examples.x: Would that he had lived to see it.

senses.definition: an injury to part of the body, especially one in which a hole is made in the skin using a weapon

examples.x: a gunshot/stab wound
a bullet/knife/shrapnel wound
a head/leg wound
an old war wound
The nurse cleaned the wound.
The wound healed slowly.
He died of his wounds.
He suffered a fatal wound to the abdomen.
He died from the wounds he had received to his chest.

senses.definition: mental or emotional pain caused by something unpleasant that has been said or done to you

examples.x: Seeing him again opened up old wounds.
They say that time heals all wounds.
After a serious argument, it can take some time for the wounds to heal.
The incident remains a festering wound.

senses.definition: to spend time trying to get your strength or confidence back after a defeat or a disappointing experience

examples.x: Leeds are still licking their wounds after their humiliating defeat by Grimsby.

senses.definition: to remind somebody of something unpleasant that happened or existed in the past

examples.x: His comments have served only to reopen old wounds.

senses.definition: to make a difficult experience even more difficult for somebody
to injure part of the body, especially by making a hole in the skin using a weapon

examples.x: He had been wounded in the arm.
The driver was seriously wounded in the shooting.
Two soldiers were wounded in yesterday's fighting.
She was fatally wounded in the attack.
His leg had been badly wounded in the helicopter crash.

senses.definition: to hurt somebody’s feelings

examples.x: She had been deeply wounded by his remarks.
Friends say he has been wounded by the criticism.
Their indifference wounded him.
You wounded his pride.
It seemed to me I had wounded her ego.

senses.definition: used to show that you are very surprised or impressed by somebody/something

examples.x: Wow! You look terrific!

senses.definition: to cover something completely in paper or other material, for example when you are giving it as a present

examples.x: He spent the evening wrapping up the Christmas presents.
individually wrapped chocolates
Each apple was wrapped in paper.
The cheese is cut and wrapped in plastic.
fish and chips wrapped up in newspaper

senses.definition: to cover something/somebody in material, for example in order to protect it/them

examples.x: Wrap the meat in foil before you cook it.
I wrapped the baby up in a blanket.
He tossed her a towel. ‘Wrap yourself in that.’
She wrapped herself up in a long shawl.
I wrapped a blanket around the baby.

senses.definition: to put something around something/somebody

examples.x: A scarf was wrapped around his neck.
The nurse wrapped a bandage tightly around my ankle.
His arms were wrapped around her waist.
He wrapped his arms tightly around her waist.
He wrapped his hands around my neck and tried to strangle me.
She's got a towel wrapped around her head.

senses.definition: to cause a word or text to be carried over to a new line as the end of the previous line is reached by the writer; to be carried over in this way

examples.x: How can I wrap the text around?
The text wraps around if it is too long to fit the screen.

senses.definition: to be so involved with somebody/something that you do not pay enough attention to other people or things

examples.x: They are completely wrapped up in their children.
She was so wrapped up in her work that she didn’t realize how late it was.

senses.definition: to persuade somebody to do anything that you want

examples.x: She has always been able to wrap her parents around her little finger.

senses.definition: the joint between the hand and the arm

examples.x: She's broken her wrist.
He wore a copper bracelet on his wrist.

senses.definition: a warning or mild punishment

examples.x: We're hoping that she gets off with a slap on the wrist from the judge.

senses.definition: to make letters or numbers on a surface, especially using a pen or a pencil

examples.x: In some countries children don't start learning to read and write until they are six.
Please write in pen on both sides of the paper.
I haven't got anything to write with.
Write your name at the top of the paper.
The teacher wrote the answers on the board.
The ‘b’ had been wrongly written as a ‘d’.

senses.definition: to produce something in written form so that people can read, perform or use it, etc.

examples.x: to write a novel/song/computer program
to write an article/essay
Who was ‘The Grapes of Wrath’ written by?
Which opera did Verdi write first?
He hopes to write a book about his experiences one day.
She had to write a report on the project.
The text is very well written.
The play was originally written for British television.
I wanted to travel and then write about it.
He writes for the ‘New Yorker’ (= works as a writer).
No decision has been made at the time of writing.
She wrote him several poems.

senses.definition: to put information, a message of good wishes, etc. in a letter or an email and send it to somebody

examples.x: Bye! Don't forget to write.
I'm writing to enquire about language courses.
She wrote to him in France.
I wrote a letter to the Publicity Department.
I wrote the Publicity Department a letter.
She wrote that they were all fine.
Write me while you're away.
He wrote me that he would be arriving Monday.
They wrote thanking us for the present.

senses.definition: to state the information or the words mentioned

examples.x: The author writes that this theory has now been disproved.
Ancient historians wrote of a lost continent beneath the ocean.
She wrote of her life in Africa.
‘Of all my books,’ wrote Dickens, ‘I like this the best.’

senses.definition: to put information in the appropriate places on a form

examples.x: to write (out) a cheque
The doctor wrote her a prescription for more antibiotics.
I'll write you out a receipt.

senses.definition: to record data in the memory of a computer

examples.x: An error was reported when he tried to write data to the file for the first time.

senses.definition: to work correctly or in the way mentioned

examples.x: This pen won't write.

senses.definition: to be very obvious to other people from the expression on somebody’s face

examples.x: Guilt was written all over his face.

senses.definition: to show clearly the quality mentioned or the influence of the person mentioned

examples.x: It was a performance with star quality written all over it.
This essay has got Mike written all over it.

senses.definition: not especially good; ordinary

examples.x: The team’s performance was nothing to write home about.

senses.definition: having no value, especially legally, or because one of the people involved has no intention of doing what they said they would
used when you are stating that there is nothing more that can be said about something or that something is completely finished

examples.x: We were doing well but we ran out of money and that’s all she wrote.

senses.definition: a person whose job is writing books, stories, articles, etc.

examples.x: Who's your favourite writer?
a travel/cookery/science fiction writer
a freelance feature writer for ‘Time’ magazine
writers of poetry/fiction
the first Russian writer to win the Nobel Prize for Literature
She left her job to become a full-time writer.

senses.definition: a person who has written a particular thing

examples.x: the writer of this letter
I used to be a prolific letter writer.

senses.definition: a person who forms letters in a particular way when they are writing

examples.x: a messy writer

senses.definition: the activity of writing, in contrast to reading, speaking, etc.

examples.x: Our son’s having problems with his reading and writing (= at school).
a writing case (= containing paper, pens, etc.)
Every morning the children do writing.

senses.definition: the activity of writing books, articles, etc., especially as a job

examples.x: Only later did she discover a talent for writing.
I wanted to try out a new style of writing.
creative writing
feminist/travel writing
He is leaving the band to concentrate on his writing.

senses.definition: books, articles, etc. in general

examples.x: The review is a brilliant piece of writing.

senses.definition: words that have been written or painted on something

examples.x: There was writing all over the desk.

senses.definition: the particular way in which somebody forms letters when they write

examples.x: Who's this from? I don't recognize the writing.

senses.definition: a group of pieces of writing, especially by a particular person or on a particular subject

examples.x: His experiences in India influenced his later writings.
the writings of Hegel
His writings on complex subjects are clear and definitive.

senses.definition: in the form of a letter, document, etc. (that gives proof of something)

examples.x: All telephone reservations must be confirmed in writing.
Could you put your complaint in writing?
You must get it in writing.

senses.definition: used when you are describing a situation in which there are signs that something is going to have problems or that it is going to be a failure

examples.x: It is amazing that not one of them saw the writing on the wall.

senses.definition: expressed in writing rather than in speech

examples.x: Having a written record of what I've done is very valuable.
written instructions
The council is inviting written submissions from the public before June 19.

senses.definition: involving writing rather than speaking or practical skills

examples.x: a written test
Students must submit one or more pieces of written work for assessment.
written communication skills

senses.definition: in the form of a letter, document, etc. and therefore official

examples.x: No portion of this site may be copied without express written consent.
You must give written permission before this information can be shared.
a written apology
a written contract
In a written statement, the government has denied the claims.

senses.definition: language expressed in writing rather than in speech

examples.x: the permanence of the written word

senses.definition: not right or correct

examples.x: I got all the answers wrong.
He was driving on the wrong side of the road.
Sorry, I must have dialled the wrong number.
You're holding the camera the wrong way up!
That picture is the wrong way round.
I soon realised I'd taken a wrong turn.
He got all his calculations wrong.
The information is just plain wrong.

senses.definition: not right about something/somebody

examples.x: I think she lives at number 44, but I could be wrong.
You were wrong about Tom; he's not married after all.
We were wrong to assume that she'd agree.
She would prove him wrong (= prove that he was wrong) whatever happened.
Correct me if I'm wrong (= I may be wrong) but didn't you say you two knew each other?
If you think I'm happy, you're dead wrong.
You think you've beaten me but that's where you're wrong.
‘I thought this might interest you because I know you like boxing.’ ‘You're not wrong (= you are absolutely right). I love boxing.’

senses.definition: causing problems or difficulties; not as it should be

examples.x: Is anything wrong? You look worried.
‘What's wrong?’ ‘Oh, nothing.’
There's something wrong with the printer.
I have something wrong with my foot.
The doctor could find nothing wrong with him.

senses.definition: not suitable, right or what you need

examples.x: He's the wrong person for the job.
She's simply wrong for this job.
I realized that it was the wrong thing to say.
Most people think that the country is heading in the wrong direction.
It was his bad luck to be in the wrong place at the wrong time (= so that he got involved in trouble without intending to).
We don't want this document falling into the wrong hands.
She's all wrong for you.

senses.definition: not morally right or honest

examples.x: This man has done nothing wrong.
It is wrong to tell lies.
It's morally wrong to kill somebody.
It was wrong of me to get so angry.
What's wrong with eating meat?
There's nothing inherently wrong with this type of nostalgia.
It is wrong that he should not be punished for what he did.

senses.definition: to support somebody/something that is not successful
to have the wrong idea about how to get or achieve something

examples.x: You're barking up the wrong tree if you're expecting us to lend you any money.

senses.definition: from or living in a poor area or part of town
to start a relationship well/badly

examples.x: I seem to have got off on the wrong foot with the new boss.

senses.definition: to make somebody pleased with you/annoyed with you
to be in a bad mood for the whole day for no particular reason
to understand something in the wrong way
to do, say or write something that is suitable/not suitable for a particular occasion

examples.x: It is a bizarre tale and the author hits just the right note of horror and disbelief.
Unfortunately, the president struck the wrong note in his speech, ignoring the public mood.

senses.definition: almost correct

examples.x: Your guess wasn't far out at all.
They weren't far out with their estimate of 100 000.
You're not far wrong when you say he's the richest guy in town.

senses.definition: younger or older than 40, 50, etc. years of age
thinking or behaving in the right/wrong way

examples.x: We haven’t found a cure yet—but we are on the right track.
The new manager successfully got the team back onto the right track.
The police were on the wrong track when they treated the case as a revenge killing.

senses.definition: in trouble with the police
to make somebody annoyed or angry, often without intending to, by doing or saying something that offends them

examples.x: She tends to rub people up the wrong way.

senses.definition: to be offended by a remark that was not intended to be offensive

examples.x: Don't take this the wrong way, but maybe you're trying a bit too hard.

senses.definition: in a way that produces a result that is not correct or that you do not want

examples.x: My name is spelt wrong.
The program won't load. What am I doing wrong?
I was trying to apologize but it came out wrong (= what I said sounded wrong).
‘I thought you were going out.’ ‘Well you must have thought wrong, then!’

senses.definition: to not understand correctly what somebody means or what they are

examples.x: Don’t get me wrong (= do not be offended by what I am going to say), I think he’s doing a good job, but…

senses.definition: to not understand a situation correctly

examples.x: No, you've got it all wrong. She's his wife.
You've got it all wrong. I never meant to imply that you were responsible.

senses.definition: to make a mistake with something

examples.x: I must have got the figures wrong.
It looks like they got their predictions wrong again.

senses.definition: to make a mistake

examples.x: If you do what she tells you, you won't go far wrong.
Where did we go wrong with those kids (= what mistakes did we make for them to behave so badly)?

senses.definition: to stop working correctly

examples.x: My watch keeps going wrong.

senses.definition: to experience problems or difficulties

examples.x: The relationship started to go wrong when they moved abroad.
What else can go wrong (= what other problems are we going to have)?
What went wrong? You were doing really well.
Something has gone badly wrong.
to go terribly/seriously wrong

senses.definition: to make a mistake

examples.x: In the last two games he has hardly put a foot wrong.

senses.definition: used to say that something will always be acceptable in a particular situation

examples.x: For a quick lunch you can't go wrong with pasta.
You can't go wrong with spaghetti—everyone likes it.

senses.definition: behaviour that is not honest or morally acceptable

examples.x: Children must be taught the difference between right and wrong.
Her son can do no wrong in her eyes.

senses.definition: an act that is not legal, honest or morally acceptable

examples.x: It is time to forgive past wrongs if progress is to be made.
It seems like we're righting a wrong. It's long overdue.

senses.definition: responsible for an accident, a mistake, an argument, etc.

examples.x: The motorcyclist was clearly in the wrong.
It took a lot of courage to admit that she was in the wrong.
Although he knew he was in the wrong, he wouldn't apologize.

senses.definition: to do something to correct an unfair situation or something bad that you have done

examples.x: This is a time to right wrongs and heal divisions.
How can we right these wrongs?

senses.definition: used to say that if somebody does something bad to you, the situation will not be improved by doing something bad to them
